newsitem.title: USA: Judge clears way for Pabst to cut retiree benefits.
newsitem.headline: Judge clears way for Pabst to cut retiree benefits.

text.p: A federal judge Friday cleared the way for Pabst Brewing Co. to cut off medical and death benefits to more than 800 retirees over the protests of the brewer's union workers.

U.S. District Court Judge Myron Gordon refused to issue a permanent injunction and lifted a temporary restraining order he put in place last month against Pabst, which said it would save $3.5 million a year by terminating retiree benefits.
Gordon said the union had little chance of succeeding in blocking the move by the 152-year-old brewer. The union said it was disappointed by the ruling, without indicating whether it would appeal.
The case has attracted the attention of Labour Secretary Robert Reich, who suggested earlier this year that Pabst was acting illegally in cutting off benefits.

Pabst is the nation's sixth-largest brewer, but it has complained of losing money for more than a year, as microbreweries and the market leader, St. Louis-based Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc., have dominated the market.
A recent industry report by PaineWebber showed Pabst's share of the domestic beer market fell to 3.9 percent in 1996 from 4.6 percent in 1995. Its sales fell the fastest of all the major brewers.
